messageBody:
J,

Here's how I'd approach it. I'll assume you already have some kind of

class Screenshotter extends TestWatcher { ... }

You'll need to take the logic from your after method, and put it into an
ExternalResource:

public class BrowserCloser extends ExternalResource {
@Override protected void after() {
// close the browser
}
}

And then, in your test class, you can include both with a RuleChain:

@Rule public TestRule chain = TestRule.outerRule(new
BrowserCloser()).around(new Screenshotter());

Hope that helps,

David

> I am Selenium Developer. I was trying to override the class: TestWatcher
> method: failed. To add some custom test failure handling (take a screenshot
> on test failure). However I noticed that the failed() method is invoked
> after the @after method is executed. Currently we are using the @after
> method to close the browser. So we need to execute takeAScreenShot() after
> a test has failed, and before the @after method is exeuted. Any
> suggestions? I didn't see a way to do this, without making some major
> changes to TestWatcher.
